title: 23.3; Clemens of Alexandria knew that this conception was Platonic and not Marcionite
The Western and Eastern school of the Valentinians held quite different views of Christ’s body; cf

Sentence 23 of the Coptic Gospel of Philippus makes clear that it denies the carnal resurrection and the fleshly body of Christ. Christ’s flesh can be identified with the spiritual body of the Logos, his blood is the Holy Spirit

title: Tert

... nous noterons que le De carne Christi tout entire est présenté dans son introduction et dans sa conclusion comme une sorte de précédent qui préjugera l’issue d’un futur débat sur la resurrection de la chair

In De carne Christi, Tertullian is mainly interested in the heretic exegesis of scripture in its context. Because of that he does not tell us much about the doctrines of the heretics. This may be the reason why he hardly mentions the Valentinian mythos; cf

note: in contrast to the first books of Adversus Marcionem.
title: For example, in his discussion with Apelles about the angelic flesh, De carn. 6.10f., or about the temptation of Christ which Apelles sees in Mt. 12.48, De carn. 7.3. 26 De carne Christi is principally a dispute about the correct understanding of some New Testament texts to which the heretics refer
55.12. The Stoics thought of a complete mixture, whereas substances and qualities remain intact, cf. SVF II 473
63.6 accuses Tertullian’s adversaries of despising the flesh and God the creator of the flesh and Christ his incarnate son
Il suffira de noter que les chrétiens, le plus souvent, concevaient l’ascetisme comme un effort destiné à fortifier et non à affaiblir le corps
